constructs.name: weekend_work
constructs.description: Amount of work done on Saturday and Sunday, including checking emails, completing tasks, or attending meetings

constructs.name: weekday_task_completion
constructs.description: Proportion of planned work tasks completed during regular weekday work hours (Monday-Friday)

constructs.name: work_urgency_perception
constructs.description: Subjective sense of deadline pressure and how urgent current work demands feel

constructs.name: boundary_enforcement
constructs.description: Active behaviors to maintain work-life separation: saying no, not checking email, turning off notifications

constructs.name: weekday_productivity
constructs.description: Efficiency and effectiveness of work output during weekday work hours

constructs.name: energy_level
constructs.description: Physical and mental energy available for work and activities throughout the day

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and restorative nature of sleep, including duration and depth

constructs.name: work_stress
constructs.description: Anxiety, worry, and mental burden related to work demands and performance

constructs.name: exercise_engagement
constructs.description: Physical activity and exercise participation during the day

constructs.name: available_focus_time
constructs.description: Hours available for uninterrupted deep work, free from meetings and interruptions

constructs.name: meeting_load
constructs.description: Time spent in scheduled meetings, calls, and synchronous work interactions

constructs.name: procrastination_behavior
constructs.description: Avoidance of work tasks, delaying important work in favor of less demanding activities

constructs.name: after_hours_connectivity
constructs.description: Checking work communications (email, Slack, etc.) outside normal work hours in evenings

constructs.name: workload_volume
constructs.description: Total amount of work tasks and responsibilities assigned or taken on

constructs.name: planning_quality
constructs.description: Effectiveness of weekly and daily planning, including realistic time estimates and prioritization

constructs.name: delegation_behavior
constructs.description: Active distribution of tasks to others and seeking help when overwhelmed

constructs.name: job_demands_profile
constructs.description: Inherent demands of the job type and industry, including baseline expectations for availability

constructs.name: organizational_culture
constructs.description: Company and team norms around work hours, responsiveness, and weekend work expectations

constructs.name: perfectionism_tendency
constructs.description: Trait-level perfectionism and need for high standards that can drive overwork

constructs.name: career_stage
constructs.description: Career level and seniority affecting autonomy, delegation ability, and expectations

constructs.name: financial_pressure
constructs.description: Level of financial obligations and concerns that may drive job insecurity and overwork

edges.description: Incomplete weekday work directly spills over into weekend work to catch up
High perceived urgency drives working weekends to meet pressing deadlines
Active boundary-setting directly reduces weekend work by creating protective barriers
Habit of checking work communications leads to getting pulled into weekend work
Work anxiety drives compulsive checking and working to reduce worry
Company norms around availability directly shape weekend work expectations
Higher daily productivity enables completing more tasks within the work week
Higher workload makes it harder to complete all tasks during weekdays
Procrastination during the week reduces task completion, creating spillover
Better planning with realistic estimates improves weekday completion rates
Higher energy enables sustained focus and efficient work output
More uninterrupted time allows for deep work and higher productivity
High stress impairs cognitive function and reduces work effectiveness
Good sleep restores physical and mental energy for the next day
Regular exercise increases overall energy levels and vitality
Physical activity improves sleep quality and duration
Work-related anxiety and rumination impair sleep quality
Checking work communications at night disrupts wind-down and sleep onset
More meetings directly reduce time available for focused work
Anxiety about difficult tasks leads to avoidance and procrastination
Low energy reduces motivation and increases task avoidance
Higher workload creates more perceived deadline pressure
Company urgency culture shapes individual perception of deadline pressure
Active delegation reduces personal workload burden
Job type determines baseline workload expectations
Job type determines how meeting-intensive the role is
More senior roles have greater ability and expectation to delegate
Career stage affects scope of responsibilities and workload
Perfectionism creates chronic worry about work quality and performance
Perfectionism undermines ability to set boundaries and accept good enough
Financial concerns create job insecurity and performance anxiety
High stress undermines confidence to enforce work-life boundaries
Supportive culture makes boundary-setting easier; always-on culture undermines it
Working weekends disrupts recovery time and sleep patterns
Working weekends increases burnout and chronic work-related stress
Company norms shape expectations around checking messages after hours
Anxiety drives compulsive checking of work communications
Higher workload creates more pressure and work-related anxiety
Good planning with clear priorities improves daily work efficiency
Higher energy makes it easier to engage in exercise
Poor sleep increases stress reactivity and reduces emotional regulation
Procrastinating on tasks creates accumulating stress about incomplete work
High stress impairs executive function needed for effective planning

indicators.name: work_browsing_weekend_count
indicators.how_to_measure: For entries on Saturday or Sunday only: count browsing entries (searches and site visits) that are work-related. Work-related includes: programming/coding topics, technical documentation, professional tools (work email, Slack, work apps), professional research. Return 0 for weekday entries.

indicators.name: any_work_on_weekend_day
indicators.how_to_measure: For Saturday or Sunday only: code 1 if ANY work-related browsing occurred (programming searches, professional tools, work email, technical research). Code 0 if all browsing is personal/leisure. Leave weekday entries uncoded.

indicators.name: weekday_work_task_count
indicators.how_to_measure: For Monday-Friday entries: count distinct work tasks or projects evident from browsing. A task = a specific problem being solved or topic researched (e.g., debugging an error, learning a framework). Each separate work topic counts as 1. Return 0 for weekend entries.

indicators.name: task_completion_signals
indicators.how_to_measure: For weekday entries: count instances suggesting task completion. Look for: a work topic that appears multiple times then stops appearing, transitions from technical research to leisure without late-night return to same topic, or searches containing 'done', 'finished', 'completed', 'solved'. Each signal counts as 1.

indicators.name: deadline_urgency_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing urgency-related terms: 'deadline', 'urgent', 'asap', 'rush', 'due date', 'overdue', 'last minute', 'crunch', 'running late', 'behind schedule'. Each matching search counts as 1.

indicators.name: late_night_work_present
indicators.how_to_measure: Code 1 if any work-related browsing (programming, professional tools, work email, technical documentation) occurs after 10:00 PM based on entry timestamps. Code 0 if no work browsing after 10pm.

indicators.name: boundary_topic_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits about: 'work-life balance', 'setting boundaries', 'do not disturb', 'turn off notifications', 'digital detox', 'disconnect from work', 'block distracting apps', 'protect personal time', 'unplug from work'.

indicators.name: work_free_evening
indicators.how_to_measure: Code 1 if there is NO work-related browsing between 7:00 PM and 10:00 PM (check timestamps). Code 0 if any work browsing (work email, Slack, professional tools, technical work searches) appears in this window.

indicators.name: is_work_related_entry
indicators.how_to_measure: For each entry on weekdays between 9am-6pm: code 1 if work-related (programming, technical research, professional tools, documentation, work communication). Code 0 if non-work (entertainment, social media, personal shopping, news). Skip entries outside this window or on weekends.

indicators.name: sustained_work_periods
indicators.how_to_measure: Review entries for the day in time order. Count distinct periods where 5 or more consecutive entries are all work-related without non-work entries interspersed. Each such uninterrupted sequence counts as 1 sustained work period.

indicators.name: early_morning_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Code 1 if any browsing entry has a timestamp before 8:00 AM. Code 0 if all entries for the day are at 8:00 AM or later. Early activity suggests higher energy or good sleep.

indicators.name: daily_browsing_volume
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the total number of browsing entries (all searches and visits) for the day, regardless of topic. Simply count every entry shown for that day.

indicators.name: post_midnight_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Code 1 if ANY browsing entry has a timestamp between 12:00 AM (midnight) and 5:00 AM. Code 0 if no entries fall within this time window.

indicators.name: sleep_problem_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about sleep problems: 'insomnia', 'can't sleep', 'trouble sleeping', 'tired', 'exhausted', 'fatigue', 'sleep quality', 'melatonin', 'sleep aid', 'why am I tired', 'sleep schedule', 'sleep tracker'. Each matching search counts as 1.

indicators.name: stress_related_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing: 'stress', 'stressed', 'anxiety', 'anxious', 'overwhelmed', 'burnout', 'burned out', 'mental health', 'therapy', 'counseling', 'meditation app', 'how to relax', 'coping', 'panic'. Each matching search counts as 1.

indicators.name: escapist_content_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to escapist content sites: gaming sites (Steam, Twitch, game wikis), streaming entertainment (Netflix, Hulu, Disney+), YouTube entertainment channels, Reddit entertainment subreddits, celebrity gossip sites, meme sites. Each visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: exercise_related_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches and visits about exercise: 'gym', 'workout', 'exercise', 'running', 'fitness', 'yoga', 'cycling', 'swimming', fitness apps (Strava, Fitbit, MyFitnessPal), exercise routines, sports activities (e.g., 'kitesurfing', 'hiking', 'climbing').

indicators.name: exercise_interest_present
indicators.how_to_measure: Code 1 if any exercise or fitness related browsing occurred (workout info, fitness tracking, sports activity, gym searches). Code 0 if no exercise-related entries are present for the day.

indicators.name: context_switches_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Review entries between 9am-6pm in time order. Count each transition from work-related to non-work or vice versa. Example: work entry → news → work = 2 switches. If all entries are same type (all work or all non-work), count is 0.

indicators.name: consecutive_work_sequences
indicators.how_to_measure: Count how many times during work hours you see 5+ consecutive work-related entries in a row without any non-work entry breaking the sequence. Each such sequence counts as 1.

indicators.name: calendar_scheduling_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to: Google Calendar, Outlook Calendar, Calendly, Doodle, calendar apps, Zoom meeting pages, Google Meet links, Microsoft Teams meeting joins. Each visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: meeting_related_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing: 'meeting', 'agenda', 'presentation', 'slides', 'standup', 'sync', 'one on one', '1:1', 'conference call', 'video call', 'zoom link', 'teams meeting'. Each matching search counts as 1.

indicators.name: distraction_visits_work_hours
indicators.how_to_measure: For weekday entries between 9am-6pm: count visits to distraction sites: Reddit, Twitter/X, Instagram, Facebook, TikTok, YouTube (non-tutorial), Netflix, news sites, sports scores, shopping sites, gaming sites. Each visit counts as 1. Return 0 for weekend or outside work hours.

indicators.name: work_distraction_alternation
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where a work-related entry is immediately followed by a distraction entry and then another work entry on the same topic (work→distraction→similar work pattern). Each such three-entry pattern counts as 1.

indicators.name: evening_work_entries
indicators.how_to_measure: Count work-related browsing entries with timestamps between 6:00 PM and 11:00 PM. Work-related includes: work email, Slack, Teams, professional technical searches, work documentation. Each entry counts as 1.

indicators.name: work_communication_evening
indicators.how_to_measure: Code 1 if any work communication tool (Slack, Microsoft Teams, work email, work chat) was visited after 6:00 PM based on timestamps. Code 0 if no such visits occurred in evening.

indicators.name: distinct_work_topics
indicators.how_to_measure: Count distinctly different work topics evident from the day's browsing. Each separate technical domain or project counts as 1. Example: Python debugging + database queries + API documentation = 3 distinct topics. Related searches on same topic count as 1 topic total.

indicators.name: total_work_entries
indicators.how_to_measure: Count all work-related browsing entries for the day: programming searches, technical documentation, professional tool visits, work email, project research. Count every work-related entry regardless of time of day.

indicators.name: planning_tool_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to planning/productivity tools: Todoist, Asana, Trello, Notion, Monday.com, project management apps, to-do list apps, time-blocking tools, calendar (for planning, not meeting joins). Each visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: productivity_method_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about planning or productivity: 'how to plan', 'productivity tips', 'time management', 'prioritize tasks', 'todo system', 'GTD', 'getting things done', 'pomodoro', 'weekly planning', 'organize work', 'task management'. Each search counts as 1.

indicators.name: delegation_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about delegating or getting help: 'how to delegate', 'assign task', 'outsource work', 'virtual assistant', 'ask for help', 'distribute workload', 'team task assignment', 'saying no to tasks'. Each matching search counts as 1.

indicators.name: collaboration_platform_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to team collaboration platforms: Slack, Microsoft Teams, Asana, Jira, GitHub (issues, pull requests), Linear, Basecamp, shared project boards. Each visit counts as 1. Higher counts suggest more team coordination.
